question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $x$ and $y$ be distinct real numbers such that
\[
\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 4 & 9 \\ 3 & x & y \\ 3 & y & x \end{vmatrix}
= 0.\]Find $x + y.$
inference:
Solution:
Expanding the determinant, we get
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 4 & 9 \\ 3 & x & y \\ 3 & y & x \end{vmatrix} &= 1 \begin{vmatrix} x & y \\ y & x \end{vmatrix} - 4 \begin{vmatrix} 3 & y \\ 3 & x \end{vmatrix} + 9 \begin{vmatrix} 3 & x \\ 3 & y \end{vmatrix} \\
&= (x^2 - y^2) - 4(3x - 3y) + 9(3y - 3x) \\
&= x^2 - y^2 - 33x + 39y.
\end{align*}Thus, $x^2 - y^2 - 33x + 39y = 0.$  This factors as $(x - y)(x + y - 33) = 0.$  Since $x$ and $y$ are distinct, $x + y - 33 = 0,$ so $x + y = \boxed{33}.$
Final Answer: $\boxed{33}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Expanding the determinant, we obtain
\begin{align*}
\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 4 & 9 \\ 3 & x & y \\ 3 & y & x \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} x & y \\ y & x \end{vmatrix} - 4 \begin{vmatrix} 3 & y \\ 3 & x \end{vmatrix} + 9 \begin{vmatrix} 3 & x \\ 3 & y \end{vmatrix} \\
&= (x^2 - y^2) - 4(3x - 3y) + 9(3y - 3x) \\
&= x^2 - y^2 - 39x + 39y \\
&= (x - y)(x + y) - 39(x - y) \\
&= (x - y)(x + y - 39).
\end{align*}Since this is 0, either $x - y = 0$ or $x + y - 39 = 0.$  But $x$ and $y$ are distinct, so $x + y = \boxed{39}.$
